title: Object-Oriented Programming (OOP)
description: OOP is a programming paradigm based on the concept of 'objects', which can contain data and code. The four main pillars of OOP in Java are:
points: Encapsulation: Bundling data and methods that operate on that data within a single unit (class).
Inheritance: Mechanism where a new class inherits properties and behaviors from an existing class.
Polymorphism: Ability of an object to take on many forms (e.g., method overloading and overriding).
Abstraction: Hiding complex implementation details and showing only the essential features of the object.

title: JVM, JRE, and JDK
description: Understanding the Java ecosystem structure is crucial for every developer.
points: JDK (Java Development Kit): The full development environment including the JRE, compilers (javac), and tools.
JRE (Java Runtime Environment): The runtime environment required to run Java applications. Includes JVM and libraries.
JVM (Java Virtual Machine): The engine that executes Java bytecode. It provides platform independence (Write Once, Run Anywhere).

title: Java Collections Framework
description: A unified architecture for representing and manipulating collections of objects.
points: List: Ordered collection (e.g., ArrayList, LinkedList). Allows duplicates.
Set: Unordered collection that does not allow duplicates (e.g., HashSet, TreeSet).
Map: Object that maps keys to values. No duplicate keys allowed (e.g., HashMap, TreeMap).
Queue: Collection used to hold multiple elements prior to processing (e.g., PriorityQueue).

title: Exception Handling
description: Mechanism to handle runtime errors and maintain normal application flow.
points: Checked Exceptions: Exceptions checked at compile-time (e.g., IOException). Must be handled.
Unchecked Exceptions: Exceptions occurring at runtime (e.g., NullPointerException). Optional handling.
Try-Catch-Finally: Block structure to handle exceptions and execute cleanup code.

title: Java Streams API
description: Introduced in Java 8 to process sequences of elements declaratively.
points: Intermediate Operations: Transform a stream into another stream (e.g., filter, map, sorted). Lazy execution.
Terminal Operations: Produce a result or side-effect (e.g., collect, forEach, reduce). Triggers processing.
Parallel Streams: Enable parallel processing of data leveraging multi-core architectures.

title: Multithreading & Concurrency
description: Concurrent execution of two or more parts of a program for maximum CPU utilization.
points: Thread Class vs Runnable Interface: Two ways to create threads.
Synchronization: Controlling access to shared resources to prevent thread interference.
Executor Framework: Higher-level API for managing thread pools and execution.

title: Inversion of Control (IoC) & DI
description: The core principle of the Spring Framework that decouples object creation from their usage.
points: IoC Container: Manages the lifecycle and configuration of application objects (Beans).
Dependency Injection (DI): Dependencies are 'injected' into objects via Constructor, Setter, or Field injection.
Benefits: Loose coupling, easier testing, and better code maintainability.

title: Aspect-Oriented Programming (AOP)
description: A paradigm to increase modularity by separating cross-cutting concerns.
points: Cross-cutting Concerns: Logic used across multiple modules (e.g., Logging, Security, Transaction).
Aspect: Module encapsulating a concern.
Advice: Action taken at a join point (Before, After, Around).

title: Spring Bean Scopes
description: Defines the lifecycle and visibility of Spring beans.
points: Singleton: Default scope. Only one instance per Spring container.
Prototype: A new instance is created every time the bean is requested.
Request/Session: Scopes specific to web-aware Spring ApplicationContext.

title: Spring MVC Flow
description: Request processing workflow in Spring Web MVC.
points: DispatcherServlet: Front controller that receives all requests.
HandlerMapping: Maps request to appropriate Controller.
ViewResolver: Resolves logical view names to actual views (JSP, Thymeleaf).

title: Spring Boot Auto-Configuration
description: Opinionated defaults to configure Spring applications automatically.
points: @EnableAutoConfiguration: Triggers auto-configuration based on classpath dependencies.
Conditional Configuration: Beans are created only if specific classes or properties are present.
Benefits: Eliminates boilerplate configuration code.

title: Spring Boot Actuator
description: Production-ready features to monitor and manage your application.
points: Endpoints: Exposes operational information (e.g., /health, /metrics, /info).
Customization: Create custom endpoints or secure existing ones.
Health Checks: Monitor database connections, disk space, and other components.

title: Key Spring Boot Annotations
description: Essential annotations for building Spring Boot applications.
points: @SpringBootApplication: Meta-annotation combining @Configuration, @EnableAutoConfiguration, and @ComponentScan.
@RestController: Specialized version of @Controller that automatically writes response to body.
@Service, @Repository, @Component: Stereotype annotations for defining beans.

title: Database Normalization
description: Process of organizing data to reduce redundancy and improve integrity.
points: 1NF: Atomic values, no repeating groups.
2NF: 1NF + no partial dependencies.
3NF: 2NF + no transitive dependencies.

title: ACID Properties
description: Guarantees for reliable database transactions.
points: Atomicity: All operations in a transaction succeed or fail together.
Consistency: Database moves from one valid state to another.
Isolation: Concurrent transactions do not affect each other.
Durability: Committed data is saved permanently.

title: Indexes
description: Data structures that improve speed of data retrieval operations.
points: Clustered Index: Sorts and stores data rows in the table based on key values (Primary Key).
Non-Clustered Index: Structure separate from data rows. Contains key values and pointers to data.
Trade-off: Faster reads (SELECT) but slower writes (INSERT/UPDATE/DELETE).

title: SQL Joins
description: Clause used to combine rows from two or more tables.
points: INNER JOIN: Returns records with matching values in both tables.
LEFT JOIN: Returns all records from left table, and matched records from right.
RIGHT JOIN: Returns all records from right table, and matched records from left.
FULL OUTER JOIN: Returns all records when there is a match in either left or right.

title: Big O Notation
description: Mathematical notation to describe algorithm efficiency.
points: O(1): Constant Time - direct access.
O(log n): Logarithmic Time - binary search.
O(n): Linear Time - simply looping through elements.
O(n log n): Linearithmic Time - effective sorting (Merge Sort, Quick Sort).
O(n^2): Quadratic Time - nested loops.

title: Common Data Structures
description: Ways of organizing and storing data for efficient access and modification.
points: Array: Contiguous memory locations. Fast access O(1), fixed size.
LinkedList: Nodes with data and address. Dynamic size, slow access O(n).
Stack: LIFO (Last In First Out). Push/Pop operations.
Queue: FIFO (First In First Out). Enqueue/Dequeue operations.
HashMap: Key-Value pairs. Fast lookups O(1) avg.

title: Essential Algorithms
description: Step-by-step procedures for calculations and data processing.
points: Sorting: Bubble, Selection, Insertion, Merge, Quick Sort.
Searching: Linear Search, Binary Search.
Graph Traversal: BFS (Breadth-First Search), DFS (Depth-First Search).
Dynamic Programming: Breaking down problems into simpler sub-problems.

title: Object-Oriented Programming (OOP) (Advanced Drill #66)
description: OOP is a programming paradigm based on the concept of 'objects', which can contain data and code. The four main pillars of OOP in Java are: [Variation focusing on scenario 66]
points: Encapsulation: Bundling data and methods that operate on that data within a single unit (class). (See reference 66)
Inheritance: Mechanism where a new class inherits properties and behaviors from an existing class. (See reference 66)
Polymorphism: Ability of an object to take on many forms (e.g., method overloading and overriding). (See reference 66)
Abstraction: Hiding complex implementation details and showing only the essential features of the object. (See reference 66)

title: Exception Handling (Advanced Drill #67)
description: Mechanism to handle runtime errors and maintain normal application flow. [Variation focusing on scenario 67]
points: Checked Exceptions: Exceptions checked at compile-time (e.g., IOException). Must be handled. (See reference 67)
Unchecked Exceptions: Exceptions occurring at runtime (e.g., NullPointerException). Optional handling. (See reference 67)
Try-Catch-Finally: Block structure to handle exceptions and execute cleanup code. (See reference 67)

title: Java Collections Framework (Advanced Drill #68)
description: A unified architecture for representing and manipulating collections of objects. [Variation focusing on scenario 68]
points: List: Ordered collection (e.g., ArrayList, LinkedList). Allows duplicates. (See reference 68)
Set: Unordered collection that does not allow duplicates (e.g., HashSet, TreeSet). (See reference 68)
Map: Object that maps keys to values. No duplicate keys allowed (e.g., HashMap, TreeMap). (See reference 68)
Queue: Collection used to hold multiple elements prior to processing (e.g., PriorityQueue). (See reference 68)

title: Java Streams API (Advanced Drill #69)
description: Introduced in Java 8 to process sequences of elements declaratively. [Variation focusing on scenario 69]
points: Intermediate Operations: Transform a stream into another stream (e.g., filter, map, sorted). Lazy execution. (See reference 69)
Terminal Operations: Produce a result or side-effect (e.g., collect, forEach, reduce). Triggers processing. (See reference 69)
Parallel Streams: Enable parallel processing of data leveraging multi-core architectures. (See reference 69)

title: Object-Oriented Programming (OOP) (Advanced Drill #139)
description: OOP is a programming paradigm based on the concept of 'objects', which can contain data and code. The four main pillars of OOP in Java are: [Variation focusing on scenario 139]
points: Encapsulation: Bundling data and methods that operate on that data within a single unit (class). (See reference 139)
Inheritance: Mechanism where a new class inherits properties and behaviors from an existing class. (See reference 139)
Polymorphism: Ability of an object to take on many forms (e.g., method overloading and overriding). (See reference 139)
Abstraction: Hiding complex implementation details and showing only the essential features of the object. (See reference 139)

points: JDK (Java Development Kit): The full development environment including the JRE, compilers (javac), and tools. (See reference 184)
JRE (Java Runtime Environment): The runtime environment required to run Java applications. Includes JVM and libraries. (See reference 184)
JVM (Java Virtual Machine): The engine that executes Java bytecode. It provides platform independence (Write Once, Run Anywhere). (See reference 184)

title: Java Collections Framework (Advanced Drill #185)
description: A unified architecture for representing and manipulating collections of objects. [Variation focusing on scenario 185]
points: List: Ordered collection (e.g., ArrayList, LinkedList). Allows duplicates. (See reference 185)
Set: Unordered collection that does not allow duplicates (e.g., HashSet, TreeSet). (See reference 185)
Map: Object that maps keys to values. No duplicate keys allowed (e.g., HashMap, TreeMap). (See reference 185)
Queue: Collection used to hold multiple elements prior to processing (e.g., PriorityQueue). (See reference 185)

title: Multithreading & Concurrency (Advanced Drill #187)
description: Concurrent execution of two or more parts of a program for maximum CPU utilization. [Variation focusing on scenario 187]
points: Thread Class vs Runnable Interface: Two ways to create threads. (See reference 187)
Synchronization: Controlling access to shared resources to prevent thread interference. (See reference 187)
Executor Framework: Higher-level API for managing thread pools and execution. (See reference 187)

title: Object-Oriented Programming (OOP) (Advanced Drill #191)
description: OOP is a programming paradigm based on the concept of 'objects', which can contain data and code. The four main pillars of OOP in Java are: [Variation focusing on scenario 191]
points: Encapsulation: Bundling data and methods that operate on that data within a single unit (class). (See reference 191)
Inheritance: Mechanism where a new class inherits properties and behaviors from an existing class. (See reference 191)
Polymorphism: Ability of an object to take on many forms (e.g., method overloading and overriding). (See reference 191)
Abstraction: Hiding complex implementation details and showing only the essential features of the object. (See reference 191)

title: JVM, JRE, and JDK (Advanced Drill #192)

JVM (Java Virtual Machine): The engine that executes Java bytecode. It provides platform independence (Write Once, Run Anywhere). (See reference 192)

title: Java Streams API (Advanced Drill #193)
description: Introduced in Java 8 to process sequences of elements declaratively. [Variation focusing on scenario 193]
points: Intermediate Operations: Transform a stream into another stream (e.g., filter, map, sorted). Lazy execution. (See reference 193)
Terminal Operations: Produce a result or side-effect (e.g., collect, forEach, reduce). Triggers processing. (See reference 193)
Parallel Streams: Enable parallel processing of data leveraging multi-core architectures. (See reference 193)

title: Exception Handling (Advanced Drill #204)
description: Mechanism to handle runtime errors and maintain normal application flow. [Variation focusing on scenario 204]
points: Checked Exceptions: Exceptions checked at compile-time (e.g., IOException). Must be handled. (See reference 204)
Unchecked Exceptions: Exceptions occurring at runtime (e.g., NullPointerException). Optional handling. (See reference 204)
Try-Catch-Finally: Block structure to handle exceptions and execute cleanup code. (See reference 204)

points: Intermediate Operations: Transform a stream into another stream (e.g., filter, map, sorted). Lazy execution. (See reference 298)
Terminal Operations: Produce a result or side-effect (e.g., collect, forEach, reduce). Triggers processing. (See reference 298)
Parallel Streams: Enable parallel processing of data leveraging multi-core architectures. (See reference 298)

title: Exception Handling (Advanced Drill #299)
description: Mechanism to handle runtime errors and maintain normal application flow. [Variation focusing on scenario 299]
points: Checked Exceptions: Exceptions checked at compile-time (e.g., IOException). Must be handled. (See reference 299)
Unchecked Exceptions: Exceptions occurring at runtime (e.g., NullPointerException). Optional handling. (See reference 299)
Try-Catch-Finally: Block structure to handle exceptions and execute cleanup code. (See reference 299)

title: JVM, JRE, and JDK (Advanced Drill #300)
description: Understanding the Java ecosystem structure is crucial for every developer. [Variation focusing on scenario 300]
points: JDK (Java Development Kit): The full development environment including the JRE, compilers (javac), and tools. (See reference 300)
JRE (Java Runtime Environment): The runtime environment required to run Java applications. Includes JVM and libraries. (See reference 300)
JVM (Java Virtual Machine): The engine that executes Java bytecode. It provides platform independence (Write Once, Run Anywhere). (See reference 300)

title: Multithreading & Concurrency (Advanced Drill #301)
description: Concurrent execution of two or more parts of a program for maximum CPU utilization. [Variation focusing on scenario 301]
points: Thread Class vs Runnable Interface: Two ways to create threads. (See reference 301)
Synchronization: Controlling access to shared resources to prevent thread interference. (See reference 301)
Executor Framework: Higher-level API for managing thread pools and execution. (See reference 301)

title: Object-Oriented Programming (OOP) (Advanced Drill #307)
description: OOP is a programming paradigm based on the concept of 'objects', which can contain data and code. The four main pillars of OOP in Java are: [Variation focusing on scenario 307]
points: Encapsulation: Bundling data and methods that operate on that data within a single unit (class). (See reference 307)
Inheritance: Mechanism where a new class inherits properties and behaviors from an existing class. (See reference 307)
Polymorphism: Ability of an object to take on many forms (e.g., method overloading and overriding). (See reference 307)
Abstraction: Hiding complex implementation details and showing only the essential features of the object. (See reference 307)

title: Java Collections Framework (Advanced Drill #309)
description: A unified architecture for representing and manipulating collections of objects. [Variation focusing on scenario 309]
points: List: Ordered collection (e.g., ArrayList, LinkedList). Allows duplicates. (See reference 309)
Set: Unordered collection that does not allow duplicates (e.g., HashSet, TreeSet). (See reference 309)
Map: Object that maps keys to values. No duplicate keys allowed (e.g., HashMap, TreeMap). (See reference 309)
Queue: Collection used to hold multiple elements prior to processing (e.g., PriorityQueue). (See reference 309)

JRE (Java Runtime Environment): The runtime environment required to run Java applications. Includes JVM and libraries. (See reference 355)
JVM (Java Virtual Machine): The engine that executes Java bytecode. It provides platform independence (Write Once, Run Anywhere). (See reference 355)

title: Object-Oriented Programming (OOP) (Advanced Drill #356)
description: OOP is a programming paradigm based on the concept of 'objects', which can contain data and code. The four main pillars of OOP in Java are: [Variation focusing on scenario 356]
points: Encapsulation: Bundling data and methods that operate on that data within a single unit (class). (See reference 356)
Inheritance: Mechanism where a new class inherits properties and behaviors from an existing class. (See reference 356)
Polymorphism: Ability of an object to take on many forms (e.g., method overloading and overriding). (See reference 356)
Abstraction: Hiding complex implementation details and showing only the essential features of the object. (See reference 356)

title: Java Streams API (Advanced Drill #357)
description: Introduced in Java 8 to process sequences of elements declaratively. [Variation focusing on scenario 357]
points: Intermediate Operations: Transform a stream into another stream (e.g., filter, map, sorted). Lazy execution. (See reference 357)
Terminal Operations: Produce a result or side-effect (e.g., collect, forEach, reduce). Triggers processing. (See reference 357)
Parallel Streams: Enable parallel processing of data leveraging multi-core architectures. (See reference 357)

title: Exception Handling (Advanced Drill #358)
description: Mechanism to handle runtime errors and maintain normal application flow. [Variation focusing on scenario 358]
points: Checked Exceptions: Exceptions checked at compile-time (e.g., IOException). Must be handled. (See reference 358)
Unchecked Exceptions: Exceptions occurring at runtime (e.g., NullPointerException). Optional handling. (See reference 358)
Try-Catch-Finally: Block structure to handle exceptions and execute cleanup code. (See reference 358)

title: Multithreading & Concurrency (Advanced Drill #359)
description: Concurrent execution of two or more parts of a program for maximum CPU utilization. [Variation focusing on scenario 359]
points: Thread Class vs Runnable Interface: Two ways to create threads. (See reference 359)
Synchronization: Controlling access to shared resources to prevent thread interference. (See reference 359)
Executor Framework: Higher-level API for managing thread pools and execution. (See reference 359)

title: Object-Oriented Programming (OOP) (Advanced Drill #426)
description: OOP is a programming paradigm based on the concept of 'objects', which can contain data and code. The four main pillars of OOP in Java are: [Variation focusing on scenario 426]
points: Encapsulation: Bundling data and methods that operate on that data within a single unit (class). (See reference 426)
Inheritance: Mechanism where a new class inherits properties and behaviors from an existing class. (See reference 426)
Polymorphism: Ability of an object to take on many forms (e.g., method overloading and overriding). (See reference 426)
Abstraction: Hiding complex implementation details and showing only the essential features of the object. (See reference 426)

Benefits: Loose coupling, easier testing, and better code maintainability. (See reference 516)

title: Indexes (Advanced Drill #1508)
description: Data structures that improve speed of data retrieval operations. [Variation focusing on scenario 1508]
points: Clustered Index: Sorts and stores data rows in the table based on key values (Primary Key). (See reference 1508)
Non-Clustered Index: Structure separate from data rows. Contains key values and pointers to data. (See reference 1508)
Trade-off: Faster reads (SELECT) but slower writes (INSERT/UPDATE/DELETE). (See reference 1508)

title: ACID Properties (Advanced Drill #1509)
description: Guarantees for reliable database transactions. [Variation focusing on scenario 1509]
points: Atomicity: All operations in a transaction succeed or fail together. (See reference 1509)
Consistency: Database moves from one valid state to another. (See reference 1509)
Isolation: Concurrent transactions do not affect each other. (See reference 1509)
Durability: Committed data is saved permanently. (See reference 1509)

title: ACID Properties (Advanced Drill #1510)
description: Guarantees for reliable database transactions. [Variation focusing on scenario 1510]
points: Atomicity: All operations in a transaction succeed or fail together. (See reference 1510)
Consistency: Database moves from one valid state to another. (See reference 1510)
Isolation: Concurrent transactions do not affect each other. (See reference 1510)
Durability: Committed data is saved permanently. (See reference 1510)

title: Database Normalization (Advanced Drill #1511)
description: Process of organizing data to reduce redundancy and improve integrity. [Variation focusing on scenario 1511]
points: 1NF: Atomic values, no repeating groups. (See reference 1511)
2NF: 1NF + no partial dependencies. (See reference 1511)
3NF: 2NF + no transitive dependencies. (See reference 1511)

points: Atomicity: All operations in a transaction succeed or fail together. (See reference 1927)
Consistency: Database moves from one valid state to another. (See reference 1927)
Isolation: Concurrent transactions do not affect each other. (See reference 1927)
Durability: Committed data is saved permanently. (See reference 1927)

title: Indexes (Advanced Drill #1928)
description: Data structures that improve speed of data retrieval operations. [Variation focusing on scenario 1928]
points: Clustered Index: Sorts and stores data rows in the table based on key values (Primary Key). (See reference 1928)
Non-Clustered Index: Structure separate from data rows. Contains key values and pointers to data. (See reference 1928)
Trade-off: Faster reads (SELECT) but slower writes (INSERT/UPDATE/DELETE). (See reference 1928)

title: SQL Joins (Advanced Drill #1929)
description: Clause used to combine rows from two or more tables. [Variation focusing on scenario 1929]
points: INNER JOIN: Returns records with matching values in both tables. (See reference 1929)
LEFT JOIN: Returns all records from left table, and matched records from right. (See reference 1929)
RIGHT JOIN: Returns all records from right table, and matched records from left. (See reference 1929)
FULL OUTER JOIN: Returns all records when there is a match in either left or right. (See reference 1929)

Durability: Committed data is saved permanently. (See reference 1930)

title: Database Normalization (Advanced Drill #1931)
description: Process of organizing data to reduce redundancy and improve integrity. [Variation focusing on scenario 1931]
points: 1NF: Atomic values, no repeating groups. (See reference 1931)
2NF: 1NF + no partial dependencies. (See reference 1931)
3NF: 2NF + no transitive dependencies. (See reference 1931)

points: INNER JOIN: Returns records with matching values in both tables. (See reference 1998)
LEFT JOIN: Returns all records from left table, and matched records from right. (See reference 1998)
RIGHT JOIN: Returns all records from right table, and matched records from left. (See reference 1998)
FULL OUTER JOIN: Returns all records when there is a match in either left or right. (See reference 1998)

title: Database Normalization (Advanced Drill #1999)
description: Process of organizing data to reduce redundancy and improve integrity. [Variation focusing on scenario 1999]
points: 1NF: Atomic values, no repeating groups. (See reference 1999)
2NF: 1NF + no partial dependencies. (See reference 1999)
3NF: 2NF + no transitive dependencies. (See reference 1999)

title: Indexes (Advanced Drill #2000)
description: Data structures that improve speed of data retrieval operations. [Variation focusing on scenario 2000]
points: Clustered Index: Sorts and stores data rows in the table based on key values (Primary Key). (See reference 2000)
Non-Clustered Index: Structure separate from data rows. Contains key values and pointers to data. (See reference 2000)
Trade-off: Faster reads (SELECT) but slower writes (INSERT/UPDATE/DELETE). (See reference 2000)

title: Database Normalization (Advanced Drill #2001)
description: Process of organizing data to reduce redundancy and improve integrity. [Variation focusing on scenario 2001]
points: 1NF: Atomic values, no repeating groups. (See reference 2001)
2NF: 1NF + no partial dependencies. (See reference 2001)
3NF: 2NF + no transitive dependencies. (See reference 2001)

title: SQL Joins (Advanced Drill #2002)
description: Clause used to combine rows from two or more tables. [Variation focusing on scenario 2002]
points: INNER JOIN: Returns records with matching values in both tables. (See reference 2002)
LEFT JOIN: Returns all records from left table, and matched records from right. (See reference 2002)
RIGHT JOIN: Returns all records from right table, and matched records from left. (See reference 2002)
FULL OUTER JOIN: Returns all records when there is a match in either left or right. (See reference 2002)

title: ACID Properties (Advanced Drill #2003)
description: Guarantees for reliable database transactions. [Variation focusing on scenario 2003]
points: Atomicity: All operations in a transaction succeed or fail together. (See reference 2003)
Consistency: Database moves from one valid state to another. (See reference 2003)
Isolation: Concurrent transactions do not affect each other. (See reference 2003)
Durability: Committed data is saved permanently. (See reference 2003)

title: Essential Algorithms (Advanced Drill #2004)
description: Step-by-step procedures for calculations and data processing. [Variation focusing on scenario 2004]
points: Sorting: Bubble, Selection, Insertion, Merge, Quick Sort. (See reference 2004)
Searching: Linear Search, Binary Search. (See reference 2004)
Graph Traversal: BFS (Breadth-First Search), DFS (Depth-First Search). (See reference 2004)
Dynamic Programming: Breaking down problems into simpler sub-problems. (See reference 2004)

title: Big O Notation (Advanced Drill #2005)
description: Mathematical notation to describe algorithm efficiency. [Variation focusing on scenario 2005]
points: O(1): Constant Time - direct access. (See reference 2005)
O(log n): Logarithmic Time - binary search. (See reference 2005)
O(n): Linear Time - simply looping through elements. (See reference 2005)
O(n log n): Linearithmic Time - effective sorting (Merge Sort, Quick Sort). (See reference 2005)
O(n^2): Quadratic Time - nested loops. (See reference 2005)

points: Array: Contiguous memory locations. Fast access O(1), fixed size. (See reference 2108)
LinkedList: Nodes with data and address. Dynamic size, slow access O(n). (See reference 2108)
Stack: LIFO (Last In First Out). Push/Pop operations. (See reference 2108)
Queue: FIFO (First In First Out). Enqueue/Dequeue operations. (See reference 2108)
HashMap: Key-Value pairs. Fast lookups O(1) avg. (See reference 2108)

title: Big O Notation (Advanced Drill #2109)
description: Mathematical notation to describe algorithm efficiency. [Variation focusing on scenario 2109]
points: O(1): Constant Time - direct access. (See reference 2109)
O(log n): Logarithmic Time - binary search. (See reference 2109)
O(n): Linear Time - simply looping through elements. (See reference 2109)
O(n log n): Linearithmic Time - effective sorting (Merge Sort, Quick Sort). (See reference 2109)
O(n^2): Quadratic Time - nested loops. (See reference 2109)
